Award.AwardTitle: Functional Roles of Small RNAs in Plant-Cyst Nematode Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration: Cyst nematodes are parasitic roundworms of plant roots that cause severe yield and quality loss in many agricultural systems. In the US, the soybean cyst nematode is the most serious pathogen problem in soybean production. Only very limited control options for these plant pathogens exist and further research into their biology is needed to uncover novel control targets. In order for cyst nematodes to be successful, they need to be able to completely change their host plant at the cellular and physiological level. At the heart of these changes are massive alterations of plant gene expression patterns under the control of the nematode, i.e., these plant parasites are able to reprogram plant cells for their own benefit. It is unknown how cyst nematodes are able to do this, but the investigators will use the model plant Arabidopsis and the beet cyst nematode to explore a new mechanism that they have shown to be involved in cyst nematode parasitism, namely the effects of plant microRNAs (miRNAs), which are powerful regulators of gene expression. The investigators will characterize four miRNAs that they have shown to be active at the site of nematode infection and they will identify additional regulatory RNAs. As a result, the scientific community will gain understanding of cyst nematode parasitism and, more importantly, this project will identify potential avenues to interfere with cyst nematode parasitism with the goal to engineer crop plants that are resistant, which would eliminate billions of dollars in yield loss world-wide. Broader impacts are the training of young scientists as well as an involvement of high school teachers who will produce a training video module on cyst nematodes, which will be an eye-opening teaching tool for students of all backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyst nematodes are microscopic roundworms that infect the root system of many crop plants and cause severe yield loss. One of the most damaging cyst nematode species is the soybean cyst nematode, which is found in all soybean producing-states and presents a serious threat to soybean production. During the infection process, cyst nematodes convert root cells into feeding sites, a very sophisticated biological process that involves dramatic changes in the expression of thousands of plant genes. Understanding how these parasites make these changes is crucial in order to develop control strategies that restrict the nematode’s ability to infect host plants. It is a particularly puzzling question to understand how the nematodes can change the activity of so many genes in a very short time span and also maintain control over all these genes so that the infection process continues unencumbered. Clearly, the nematodes must use the host plant’s endogenous regulatory mechanisms to exert control over these genes.  In this project, the investigators have uncovered key regulatory switches that the nematode targets and which in turn then alter the expression of thousands of genes. More specifically, the investigators have identified plant genes known as microRNAs that play vital roles in the formation and function of the nematode feeding site. The investigators characterized four miRNA genes and revealed how the nematode manipulates the expression of these miRNAs in order to take control over a high number of plant genes with functions required for successful parasitism. Also, the investigators identified a significant number of new miRNAs that are active in the nematode infection sites. Additionally, the investigators identified and characterized a nematode effector protein, which functions in association with miRNAs and promotes nematode infection. As a result, the scientific community gained a better understanding of how cyst nematodes infect host plants, and more importantly, the project has identified several target genes that can be used to enhance plant resistance to cyst nematodes. Because many of these targets are conserved in various plant species, the results obtained are of broad impacts and have the potential to be directly translated to crop plants to enhance nematode resistance, which would eliminate billions of dollars in yield loss every year. Broader impacts of this project included the training of high school teachers, significant numbers of undergraduate students and young scientists.  The broader impacts also included the development of a teaching module entitled ‘Trouble at Grainly Farms’ (http://site.iptv.org/grainly-farms/home), which is accompanied by five high-quality teaching videos. These teaching videos have been produced in collaboration with Iowa Public Television (IPTV) and are currently hosted on IPTV’s YouTube channel and on PBS Learning Media. This teaching module has been tested in university and high school classrooms and has been proven to be effective.  The module will continue to be used in the coming years, and then a cumulative scientific publication will report the outcomes to the scientific community and a news release will serve to inform the general public.
